webTitle: Bank bonuses top the news again - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• Barclays’ Jenkins says payouts rose to stop “death spiral”
  • Lloyds chief executive paid £7.5m last year in total
  • Treasury committee’s Tyrie says banks must reform pay
  • Standard Chartered cuts its bonus pool by 15%
fields.body:
3.09pm GMT

Waiting for Barclays

We had expected Barclays to publish its annual report by now but there’s nothing yet.

The blog is pretty much finished for the day but we may post an update when Barclays’ report comes out.

Otherwise, there will be a story online promptly with the important details.

2.52pm GMT

Lloyds pays boss £900k to get round bonus cap

Lloyds Banking Group plans to pay chief executive Antonio Horta-Osorio a fixed payment of about £900,000 to get round the EU’s bonus cap, the bank said in its annual report.

Horta-Osório – whose total pay in 2013 was £7.5m – is receiving the shares on top of his £1.1m a year salary to ensure he does not suffer a fall in his earnings as a result of the cap.

Jill Treanor’s story about Lloyd’ pay is here.

Lloyds said it would seek shareholder approval to pay key staff bonuses worth 200 percent of their fixed pay. Under the EU rule, banks can only pay a bonus of up to one times salary unless shareholders authorise that to be doubled.

Jill Treanor tweets that UK Financial Investments, which manages the government’s 33% Lloyds stake, won’t say whether it will support the bonus plans:

Updated at 3.07pm GMT

2.15pm GMT

Lloyds annual report

Lloyds Banking Group has published its annual report, which of course contains details about pay.

There are questions over what the banks paid last year and what they intend to do this year now that the EU bonus cap is in force.

My colleague Jill Treanor is tweeting Lloyds’ highlights:

2.09pm GMT

Bank bonuses are likely to dominate the rest of the day’s business news when Barclays and Lloyds Banking Group publish their annual reports.

Just to recap, Barclays boss Antony Jenkins has already said today that the bank increased bonuses for investment bankers to stop a potential “death spiral” of departures in the US.

Andrew Tyrie, chairman of the Treasury select committee, has hit back at Jenkins over his criticism of proposals for longer-term bonuses.

Standard Chartered cut its bonus pool for last year by 15% to £772m.

Lloyds has just published its annual report. More to come.

1.32pm GMT

How to fix (mend) the currency market

After the Bank of England suspended an official, Mark Taylor, the dean at Warwick Business School, has suggested an apparently simple way to prevent rigging of the currency market.

Taylor, a former Bank of England and IMF economist and foreign exchange trader, said.

One solution would be to take away the temptation to do this by taking the London 4pm fix average over an hour - so 30 minutes either side of 4pm rather than 30 seconds. It’s a simple, workable solution because it would be a lot harder, if not impossible, to move a market as big as the FX market for an hour. Removing the incentive is much better than regulation because of the global, decentralised nature of the foreign exchange market.

1.24pm GMT

Bank of England to publish report on FX claims

There’s more detail on the Bank of England’s investigation of claims that officials condoned information sharing in the foreign currency markets.

Apart from the suspension of an unidentified Bank employee, the main news is that the Bank’s court (equivalent to its board of directors) has ordered an extension of the investigation.

City law firm Travers Smith has helped the Bank’s own lawyers with the investigation so far. The firm will now carry out a further inquiry for the court and the Bank will publish its report.

The Bank didn’t give any hint when the investigation might finish.

You can read Jill Treanor’s story here.

1.16pm GMT

Tyrie responds to Barclays' Jenkins on bonuses

Andrew Tyrie, chairman of the Treasury select committee, doesn’t appear impressed by Antony Jenkins’ comments about bonuses.

Barclays boss Jenkins said Barclays increased bonuses in 2013 despite a fall in profits to prevent a “death spiral” of departures at its US investment bank.

He also criticised proposals that some bonuses should be deferred for 10 years. The idea was put forward by the parliamentary banking commission, chaired by Tyrie.

Here’s Tyrie’s rejoinder:

The payment of a bonus should be contingent on performance. It should not be a guaranteed part of remuneration.

In some cases, performance is evident early on, in others it is not. Risks to banks, the financial system or customers from certain decisions may not become clear for some years. The Banking Commission recommended that in these cases the rewards should be much more closely aligned to the maturity of the risk, with deferral of some remuneration for up 10 years.

This recommendation was accepted by the Government, Opposition, and both main regulators. The regulators will consult on its implementation later in the year - Mr Jenkins’ reservation about deferral for longer than three years can be addressed then.

It is regrettable that a number of banks appear not to have accepted the need for fundamental reform in this year’s bonus round. The new consensus emerging on pay remains seriously flawed. It will now be up to regulators to do the job.

12.57pm GMT

London is tops for the super-rich

London has held on to its crown - if that’s the word - as the favourite city of the global super-rich, according to a report by estate agents Knight Frank.

The full story by my colleague Julia Kollewe is here.

London vies with New York as the top city for the wealthy to buy property but both will be eclipsed by Asian cities in the coming decades.

Here’s Liam Bailey, head of residential research at Knight Frank:

History, location and their long-established wealth mean that London and New York’s positions look unassailable, at least for now. It is further down our leader board that the real city wars are being waged. The main battleground is Asia, where a handful of locations are slugging it out in the hope of establishing a clear lead as the region’s alpha urban hub.

12.02pm GMT

EU announces €11bn aid for Ukraine

The European Union has said it will provide €11bn of aid to Ukraine over the next two years, European Commission President Jose Manuel Barroso has announced.

The loans and grants would be delivered in coordination with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the European Investment Bank. The packaged depends partly on Ukraine signing a deal with the International Monetary Fund.

“The package combined could bring an overall support of at least €11bn over the next couple of years, from the EU budget and EU-based international financial institutions,” Barroso said, according to Reuters.

The EU also intends to bring forward trade benefits Ukraine would have received if it had signed an association agreement with the EU last year. It will also work on providing energy to Ukraine through “reverse flows” of gas from the EU.

11.36am GMT

More reaction to the UK PMI survey. Here’s Andrew Goodwin, senior economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club:

Today’s PMI services survey provides further evidence that the UK recovery is still going strong. Although headline business activity index ticked down a touch on its level in January, it still remains well above the historical average.

Taking February’s three activity surveys together, we appear set for another quarter of GDP growth at around 0.7% in Q1 2014, which keeps us on track for growth in the region of 2.7% over the year as a whole.

The finer details of the services survey provide further good news, supporting the notion of a broader economic recovery. Rising backlogs and upbeat business confidence should support continued strength in business investment, which are shown to be performing particularly well in the latest national accounts.

The strength of business sentiment is also being reflected in employment growth, which increased at a record pace in February. This is likely to translate into stronger wage growth, as companies begin to face skills shortages, fostering sustained strength in consumer spending.

11.15am GMT

Bank of England suspends staff member after FX inquiry

The Bank of England says its inquiry into allegations that senior staff colluded with currency traders has found no evidence to support the claims.

However, the Bank has suspended an employee while it investigates whether the person complied fully with internal controls.

The Bank’s oversight committee has also appointed City law firm Travers Smith to prepare a report into whether officials colluded or knew about collusion in the currency markets. Travers Smith has been supporting the Bank’s internal review till now.

Here is the Bank’s statement:

It is a matter of public record that the Bank of England has been conducting an internal review into allegations that Bank of England officials condoned or were informed of manipulation in the foreign exchange market or the sharing of confidential client information. This extensive review of documents, emails and other records has to date found no evidence that Bank of England staff colluded in any way in manipulating the foreign exchange market or in sharing confidential client information. However, the Bank requires its staff to follow rigorous internal control processes and has today suspended a member of staff, pending investigation by the Bank into compliance with those processes.

The Bank of England does not condone any form of market manipulation in any context whatsoever. The Bank has today re-iterated its guidance to staff regarding management of records and escalation of important information. Those policies have been updated in recent months. In addition, the Oversight Committee of the Bank’s Court of Directors will lead an investigation to assess whether Bank officials were: (a) either (i) involved in attempted or actual manipulation of the foreign exchange market (including the WMR FX benchmark), or (ii) aware of attempted or actual manipulation of the foreign exchange market , or (iii) aware of the potential for such manipulation or (iv) colluded with market participants in relation to any such manipulation or aware of any such collusion between participants; (b) either (i) involved in the sharing of confidential client information or (ii) aware of the sharing of such information between participants for the purposes of transacting business in the foreign exchange market; or (c) involved in, or aware of, any other unlawful or improper behaviour or practices in the foreign exchange market.

The Oversight Committee has appointed external legal counsel, Travers Smith LLP, to prepare a report. That report will be published in due course. Travers Smith has hitherto been supporting the Bank in its internal review.

All releases are available online at www.bankofengland.co.uk/publications/Pages/news/default.aspx

No decision has been taken on disciplinary action against any member of Bank staff. The Bank continues to support the Financial Conduct Authority’s investigation into the foreign exchange market. In these circumstances, it would not be appropriate for the Bank to make any further comment on this matter.

10.53am GMT

Russia to seize company assets if sanctions imposed - report

CNN, citing state media, tweets that Russia plans to confiscate assets of US and EU companies if sanctions are imposed over Ukraine.

For updates on the Ukraine crisis, you can follow the Guardian’s live blog here.

10.33am GMT

Eurozone GDP growth confirmed at 0.3%

Eurozone GDP growth was 0.3% in the final quarter of last year.

Here’s IHS Global Insight’s Howard Archer:

While still far from dynamic, It was a step back in the right direction after growth had slowed to just 0.1% in the third quarter. Furthermore, it marked a third successive quarter of expansion following six quarters of contraction through to the first quarter of 2013. It also meant that Eurozone GDP was up 0.5% year-on-year in the fourth quarter of 2013, which was the first annual growth since the fourth quarter of 2011. Nevertheless, Eurozone GDP still contracted 0.4% overall in 2013...

While consumer spending was lacklustre across the Eurozone in the fourth quarter of 2013, a 1.6% month-on-month jump in retail sales in January after a drop of 1.3% in December raises hopes that Eurozone consumers will be more sprightly over the coming months, supported by improved confidence overall, stabilizing employment and very low inflation. Even so, unemployment across the Eurozone is still very high while purchasing power is limited by generally low wage growth, so any pick-up in consumer spending looks likely to be gradual.

10.20am GMT

UK economy has "considerable momentum"

Here’s some reaction to the UK’s strong services sector figures from Samuel Tombs at Capital Economics:

February’s UK CIPS/Markit services survey suggests that the economic recovery still has considerable momentum. The survey’s headline activity index of 58.2 was essentially unchanged from January’s 58.3 reading. The index therefore remains consistent on the basis of past form with strong quarterly gains in services output of about 1%. Meanwhile, the rise in the future activity index from 74.3 to 74.7 and the increase in the new business index from 58.9 to 59.2 suggest that the sector’s near-term outlook is bright.

Taken together with the manufacturing and construction surveys, the services PMI is consistent on the basis of past relationships with quarterly GDP growth of as much as 1.5%. Admittedly, it would be unwise to take this reading at face value, as the surveys proved to be far too upbeat in Q3 and Q4. Nonetheless, with business and consumer confidence strengthening, credit constraints loosening and the squeeze on real pay easing, the UK economy should experience another year of robust growth in 2014. Indeed, we still expect GDP to grow by about 3%, which would mark the fastest year of expansion since 2007.

10.11am GMT

Standard Chartered cuts bonus pool as profits fall

Standard Chartered has cut its bonus pool and warned that business would stay difficult in the first half of 2014 after annual profit fell for the first time in a decade.

The London-based bank, which makes almost all its profit in Asia, Africa and the Middle East, cut its 2013 bonus pool 15% to £772m.

The bank, which defied the financial crisis to produce record profits every year, has had a tough time of it recently, especially in Korea, where it has had to write down $1bn of the value of its biggest acquisition.

The bank’s shares rose following the announcement after its capital position came in stronger than expected. Some analysts have warned that lower profits could leave the bank short of capital.

Here’s chief executive Peter Sands from the results statement:

2013 was not a great year for Standard Chartered, and 2014 will inevitably have its own challenges, but we are very clear on what we have to do. We are making changes to adapt to the new realities. We have a strong balance sheet, great client relationships and superb capabilities.

Our outlook for 2014 is one of modest growth. Market and trading conditions are more volatile and difficult than a year ago. While current performance momentum is ahead of the second half of last year, performance in the first half of 2014 will remain challenged both at an income and profit level.

And here’s some more detail, courtesy of Reuters:

The bank said its pretax profit was $7 billion in 2013, down 7 percent from the year before. It had warned in December profits would fall due to losses in Korea, weak investmentbanking income and a slowdown in Asia’s economic growth.

The bank’s shares were up 3.3 percent in early trade, having tumbled 28 percent in the last year, compared with a 19 percent rally by European banks as a whole. The stock had fallen earlier this week to not far from its lowest point for the year so far.

Sands said the bank was targeting double-digit earnings growth as a “longer-term aspiration”, given slower income growth generally and pressure in Korea market, where higher loans losses have prompted the bank to shrink its business, putting some units up for sale and axing hundreds of jobs.

The bank is selling businesses and emphasising cost control and Sands confirmed the bank was seeking buyers for a Hong Kong consumer finance business. The bank is also selling a consumer finance business in Korea.

Sands reorganised the bank’s structure in January and on Wednesday identified private banking, trade finance and banking services for mid-sized corporates as three areas of focus. The bank plans to more than double its assets under management by 2020 to $300 billion.

9.54am GMT

UK services continue to grow strongly

Business activity in UK services dipped slightly last month but a survey showed the sector still powering ahead.

The Markit/CIPS purchasing managers index was 58.2, down from January’s 58.3 but orders rose more quickly and optimism about the coming year hit its highest for four and a half years.

Job growth increased to its fastest rate since at least January 1998.

Markit economist Chris Williamson said the survey suggested the economy would grow at its fastest this year since 2007.

Here’s Reuters early story:

British companies hired staff at the fastest pace in at least 16 years last month, according to a business survey on Wednesday that showed strong economic growth has carried over into the first quarter.

Although Markit/CIPS’ services purchasing managers’ index (PMI) slipped in February to 58.2, its lowest level since June, from 58.3 in January, it still showed robust growth at firms ranging from banks to hairdressers despite bad weather.

Readings above 50 signify growth, which has been the case for 14 straight months now.

Orders in the economy’s dominant sector grew more quickly and optimism about the coming year rose to its highest in 4-1/2 years.

The composite index combining PMIs for manufacturing and construction, released earlier this week, plus the services sector edged down to 58.6 in February from January’s 59.1.

But a composite subindex showed the fastest rate of jobs growth since at least January 1998, when the data series first began.

Overall, survey compiler Markit said the data pointed to economic growth of around 0.7 percent from January through March - the same as in the final three months of last year.

“There’s no end in sight to the good news,” said Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit.

9.35am GMT

Eurozone businesses expand at fastest pace since 2011

Businesses in the eurozone had their fastest growth for more than two and a half years, the Markit composite purchasing managers index showed.

The growth was led by the region’s services sector, which expanded quicker than originally thought.

Here’s Reuters’ early story:

Euro zone private businesses enjoyed their fastest growth rate in over 2-1/2 years last month as the region’s service industry expanded quicker than initially thought, surveys showed on Wednesday.

The upturn in the 18-member bloc’s fortunes was again led by Germany, but the gulf between growth in Europe’s biggest economy and the decline in France has only been wider once in the 16-year history of the surveys.

Markit’s final Eurozone Composite Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI), which gauges business activity across thousands of companies and is seen as a good guide to economic health, was revised up to 53.3 from an initial flash reading of 52.7.

That was the eighth month the index has been above the 50 mark that separates growth from contraction and beat January’s 52.9.

The surveys suggest the region’s economy was on course to grow 0.4-0.5 percent in the first quarter, Markit said, more than the 0.3 percent growth predicted in a Reuters poll last month and would be the fastest expansion in three years.

“The final PMI indicates that the euro zone economy grew at the fastest rate since June 2011, contrasting with the slowdown signalled by the flash reading,” said Chris Williamson, chief economist at survey compiler Markit.

“However, regional divergences remain a concern,” he added.

Germany’s composite PMI soared to a 33-month high but France’s fell further below the break-even mark where it has languished for most of the past two years. Italy and Spain, the third and fourth biggest economies in the bloc, both had robust growth.

Here’s Markit’s tweet on the composite index:

And on services:

9.23am GMT

Savers and borrowers - the impact of low rates

As the MPC starts its meeting, some papers are running stories on the effects of five years of record low interest rates on different groups.

The Times reports (£) that near-zero rates have cost savers £117bn. That’s the figure from the Save Our Savers campaign, which calculates that if rates had stayed at precrisis levels of 5.25% savings would be worth the equivalent of £4,500 more for every household.

The alternative view, made strongly by the Bank of England, is that if rates hadn’t come down sharply the economy would have been completely wrecked, devastating savers and borrowers alike.

City AM, published for free in London, reports that in the last five years more than a million homes were bought by first-time buyers who have only known low interest rates. The paper says these homeowners may not have prepared for rate rises when they finally happen.

9.12am GMT

China services activity rises slightly

With services surveys coming out in the EU and UK, here’s a quick catchup on the services data from China overnight.

Here’s what Reuters reported:

Activity in China’s services industry ticked up in February from a 2-1/2-year low the previous month, a private survey showed on Wednesday, confirming other data showing a pick-up in services even as manufacturing activity slows.

The HSBC/Markit Services Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) rose to 51.0 in February from January’s 50.7, buoyed by new orders, remaining above the 50 line that separates expansion from contraction.

The rise tallied with the official non-manufacturing PMI, released earlier in the week, which showed activity at a three-month high, and contrasted with two surveys that showed manufacturing activity slowed in the month.

“February data signalled stronger expansions of business activity and new work at Chinese service-sector firms,” HSBC/Markit said in a statement.

“That said, the rates of growth remained subdued in the context of historical data.”

9.07am GMT

Barclays' and LIoyds' annual reports highlight pay

There’s plenty of banking news expected today.

Barclays and Lloyds Banking Group are set to publish their annual reports and Standard Chartered has announced its full-year results.

Attention will inevitably turn to pay. Barclays and Lloyds are expected to reveal they are handing their bosses Antony Jenkins and António Horta-Osório new share awards, on top of their salaries, to prevent their overall pay falling as a result of the EU’s bonus cap.

As we report today, one of the architects of the cap has called on the European Commission to sue the UK for ignoring the cap and allowing “absurd remuneration packages”.

In today’s Telegraph, Barclays’ Jenkins says the bank increased bonuses despite falling profits to prevent a “death spiral” as bankers quit Barclays in the US. The paper says the annual report will show the number of staff paid more than £1m rose from 428 to between 475 and 500.

Here’s my colleague Jill Treanor’s story on the subject.

Updated at 11.30am GMT

8.50am GMT

BoE policymakers meet on fifth anniversary of low rates

The Bank of England’s Monetary Policy Committee starts its two-day meeting today - which is the fifth anniversary of record low interest rates.

Governor Mark Carney is facing down market pressure to start increasing rates, arguing that the economic recovery is not yet firmly entrenched. Booming business and housing survey data have fuelled calls for a rate rise.

Figures overnight showing prices in shops falling at their fastest pace for at least seven years could make Carney’s position slightly easier. The purchasing managers index for services, which make up more than three-quarters of UK GDP, comes out at 9:30am.

My colleague Nick Mead has come up with lots of charts to show who has won and lost in the time since rates were slashed to 0.5%. Below is a chart showing interest rates for personal loans and mortgages. For all the charts, click here.

8.43am GMT

ECB set to loosen monetary policy

It’s monetary policy week for the European Central Bank and the Bank of England. Both central banks announce their decisions on interest rates tomorrow facing different pressures.

The ECB is struggling to revive the eurozone economy with unemployment stuck at 12% and persistent fears that below-target inflation could lead to deflation. So today’s services PMI survey for the European Union will be closely watched ahead of the ECB’s announcement tomorrow.

Reuters reports that the ECB is already primed to loosen monetary policy:

The European Central Bank is poised to take action to loosen lending conditions and drag inflation out of a “danger zone” that threatens to stagnate the euro zone‘s fragile recovery.

Inflation is running at 0.8 percent, far below the ECB’s target of just under 2 percent, and banks’ early repayment of bumper loans they took from the central bank is draining funds from the financial system - effectively tightening policy.

Reversing this by ending operations to soak up money spent on Greek and other countries’ bonds at the height of the euro debt crisis is the prime option for ECB policymakers at Thursday’s meeting.

An ECB source predicted there would be unanimous agreement to end so-called sterilisation of the bond purchases under the bank’s Securities Markets Programme (SMP).

The resultant release of around 175 billion euros ($242 billion) would roughly double the amount of excess liquidity in the euro zone financial system, help bring down interbank lending rates and could also lower the euro’s exchange rate against the dollar, the source told Reuters.

7.58am GMT

Good morning.

After two days of gyrations caused by the Ukraine crisis, markets are expected to respond more to the regular flow of economic and company news.

It’s a big day for business surveys with purchasing managers’ indexes for services published for the EU, Germany and the UK. The closely watched reports come as Eurozone and UK ratesetters prepare to announce monetary policy tomorrow.

The Bank of England says its inquiry into allegations that senior staff colluded with currency traders has found no evidence to support the claims. This extensive review of documents, emails and other records has to date found no evidence that Bank of England staff colluded in any way in manipulating the foreign exchange market or in sharing confidential client information. However, the Bank requires its staff to follow rigorous internal control processes and has today suspended a member of staff, pending investigation by the Bank into compliance with those processes. The Bank of England does not condone any form of market manipulation in any context whatsoever. The Bank has today re-iterated its guidance to staff regarding management of records and escalation of important information. Those policies have been updated in recent months. In addition, the Oversight Committee of the Bank’s Court of Directors will lead an investigation to assess whether Bank officials were: (a) either (i) involved in attempted or actual manipulation of the foreign exchange market (including the WMR FX benchmark), or (ii) aware of attempted or actual manipulation of the foreign exchange market , or (iii) aware of the potential for such manipulation or (iv) colluded with market participants in relation to any such manipulation or aware of any such collusion between participants; (b) either (i) involved in the sharing of confidential client information or (ii) aware of the sharing of such information between participants for the purposes of transacting business in the foreign exchange market; or (c) involved in, or aware of, any other unlawful or improper behaviour or practices in the foreign exchange market. CNN, citing state media, tweets that Russia plans to confiscate assets of US and EU companies if sanctions are imposed over Ukraine. For updates on the Ukraine crisis, you can follow the Guardian’s live blog here. Eurozone GDP growth was 0.3% in the final quarter of last year. Here’s IHS Global Insight’s Howard Archer: While still far from dynamic, It was a step back in the right direction after growth had slowed to just 0.1% in the third quarter. Furthermore, it marked a third successive quarter of expansion following six quarters of contraction through to the first quarter of 2013. It also meant that Eurozone GDP was up 0.5% year-on-year in the fourth quarter of 2013, which was the first annual growth since the fourth quarter of 2011. Nevertheless, Eurozone GDP still contracted 0.4% overall in 2013... Here’s some reaction to the UK’s strong services sector figures from Samuel Tombs at Capital Economics: February’s UK CIPS/Markit services survey suggests that the economic recovery still has considerable momentum. The survey’s headline activity index of 58.2 was essentially unchanged from January’s 58.3 reading. The index therefore remains consistent on the basis of past form with strong quarterly gains in services output of about 1%. Meanwhile, the rise in the future activity index from 74.3 to 74.7 and the increase in the new business index from 58.9 to 59.2 suggest that the sector’s near-term outlook is bright. It had warned in December profits would fall due to losses in Korea, weak investmentbanking income and a slowdown in Asia’s economic growth. The bank’s shares were up 3.3 percent in early trade, having tumbled 28 percent in the last year, compared with a 19 percent rally by European banks as a whole. The stock had fallen earlier this week to not far from its lowest point for the year so far. The ECB is struggling to revive the eurozone economy with unemployment stuck at 12% and persistent fears that below-target inflation could lead to deflation. So today’s services PMI survey for the European Union will be closely watched ahead of the ECB’s announcement tomorrow. Reuters reports that the ECB is already primed to loosen monetary policy: The European Central Bank is poised to take action to loosen lending conditions and drag inflation out of a “danger zone” that threatens to stagnate the euro zone‘s fragile recovery. Inflation is running at 0.8 percent, far below the ECB’s target of just under 2 percent, and banks’ early repayment of bumper loans they took from the central bank is draining funds from the financial system - effectively tightening policy. Reversing this by ending operations to soak up money spent on Greek and other countries’ bonds at the height of the euro debt crisis is the prime option for ECB policymakers at Thursday’s meeting. An ECB source predicted there would be unanimous agreement to end so-called sterilisation of the bond purchases under the bank’s Securities Markets Programme (SMP). The resultant release of around 175 billion euros ($242 billion) would roughly double the amount of excess liquidity in the euro zone financial system, help bring down interbank lending rates and could also lower the euro’s exchange rate against the dollar, the source told Reuters. Good morning. After two days of gyrations caused by the Ukraine crisis, markets are expected to respond more to the regular flow of economic and company news. It’s a big day for business surveys with purchasing managers’ indexes for services published for the EU, Germany and the UK. The closely watched reports come as Eurozone and UK ratesetters prepare to announce monetary policy tomorrow.

webTitle: Barclays chief Antony Jenkins defends bonus payouts in year of falling profits

fields.standfirst: Before the publication of the bank's 2013 annual report, Jenkins stands by bonus culture as a strategy to avoid a "death spiral"
fields.body:
Antony Jenkins has sought to defend the bonus culture at Barclays as the bank prepares to hand him up to £1m in shares to sidestep the bonus cap.

In the wake of the furore caused by a decision to increase bonuses by 10%, following a 32% fall in profits, the Barclays boss told the Daily Telegraph he was attempting to avoid a "death spiral" after an increase in the number of staff leaving.

When the bank publishes its annual report – possibly as soon as Wednesday – it will also reveal that is has paid more than £1m to more staff in 2013 than the 428 who received at least that sum in 2012.

As he criticised demands from regulators and the parliamentary commission on banking standards to defer bonuses for up to 10 years, Jenkins said the cutback in bonuses the previous year had left the bank in "a situation where the business begins to contract".

"People are less attracted to come to you, both clients and employees," he said. "You get into something of a death spiral. Your brand deteriorates, and you can move very quickly from being a first tier player to one in the second or third tier if you don't protect the franchise."

As many as 700 staff are believed to have walked out of the group's US investment bank, and the rate of resignations among senior directors doubled to nearly 10%.

Details of millions of pounds of share awards to top bankers are to be revealed soon, as the banks attempt to prevent pay falling as a result of the bonus cap. This limits bonuses to 100% of salary, or 200% if shareholders approve. All the banks are preparing to ask shareholders to back bonuses up to 200% of salaries.

Bailed-out Lloyds Banking Group is also expected to admit on Wednesday that its boss Antonio Horta-Osorio will receive an additional tranche of shares on top of a £1m salary and £1.7m bonus for 2013.

The move follows the decision by HSBC to hand its chief executive the equivalent of £32,000 extra per week – some £1.7m a year – although his overall potential paypacket will fall.

By awarding a similar "allowance" to Horta-Osorio, Lloyds will be giving the impression that the government is endorsing such ways to sidestep the bonus cap, as the bank is 33% owned by the taxpayer.

Such moves have infuriated Philippe Lamberts, the Belgian MEP who helped devise the bonus cap, who is calling on the European Commission to sue the UK for breaches of the directive covering the bonus cap.

Royal Bank of Scotland is also thought likely to follow the moves by rivals – further inflaming the controversy, as it is 81% taxpayer-owned.

When Jenkins was appointed to take over Barclays from Bob Diamond, following the June 2012 fine for rigging Libor, he promised to cut back bonuses and a give greater share of revenues to shareholders.

"We were faced with a very difficult decision for me personally as chief executive and for the board because we are absolutely committed to driving the level of compensation down in the investment bank," Jenkins said.

Chancellor of the exchequer George Osborne has already begun legal action against the cap because he fears it will increase risks in the banking system, and a spokesperson for the commission on banking standards insisted it is too soon to know if the directive had been breached.

Jenkins waived his own bonus for 2013, which could have been as much as £2.7m, after the bank tapped shareholders for £5.8m last year.

webTitle: Five years of ultra-low interest rates - in seven simple interactive line charts

fields.standfirst: Who has won and who has lost since the MPC slashed rates to 0.5% on 5 March 2009?
fields.body:
The five years since the monetary policy committee cut the base rate to 0.5% – the lowest since the Bank of England was founded in 1694 – have been a boon for borrowers and a sore point for savers. But rock-bottom interest rates will not be around forever.

Last summer Threadneedle Street was expecting rates to stay on hold until 2016 – but in the past six months the most likely date of a rate hike has come forward to the first half of 2015.

The charts below explore who has won and who has lost over the past five years – and the factors the MPC will consider as it decides when to raise rates.

As this chart based on data from the Bank of England shows, average interest rates on fixed mortgages and personal loans have been at historic lows.

But the situation has been nothing to celebrate for pensioners and savers. Pensions expert Ros Altmann calculates that someone with a £100,000 standard variable rate mortgage has been £3,290 a year better off since the rate cut, while someone with £100,000 in a cash ISA has been £4,260 a year worse off.

The chart above shows savings rates on instant access accounts, fixed rate bonds and cash ISAs languishing at rock bottom.

Last August Bank of England governor Mark Carney said that he would not consider raising rates until the unemployment rate (then at 7.8%), fell below 7%. At that time the Bank was not expecting the jobless rate to fall to the threshold until early 2016.

But as the chart above shows, the unemployment rate has fallen faster than expected – to 7.1% in the three months to November before rising to 7.2% in the latest data, the three months to December.

Carney revised forward guidance as he presented his inflation report last month.

A lack of inflationary pressure, spare capacity, and "headwinds" at home and abroad, meant that the base rate "may need to remain at low levels for some time to come", the report said.

As the next chart shows, the services sector has now surpassed its pre-recession peak by 1.3% – but GDP as a whole has not yet caught up with where it was in the first quarter of 2008.

The production sector remains 12.3% below peak, with manufacturing still down 8.8% and construction off 11.3%.

As the chart above shows, inflation as measured by the Consumer Prices Index (CPI) has recently fallen below the Bank's 2% target for the first time in years.

But there are increasing concerns about a bubble in the housing market.

In the chart above Nationwide figures show the average price of a home in Britain rose for the 14th consecutive month in February to £177,846 – the highest since April 2008.

A regional breakdown of the Nationwide figures (below) shows much of the increase is down to price rises in London and the south-east.

But a survey this week by property researchers Hometrack found prices were up in more than half the country for the first time in 10 years.

webTitle: Qantas inquiry to investigate airline’s financial problems

fields.standfirst: Senate committee likely to consider what initiatives should be taken by the Abbott government to protect aviation jobs
fields.body:
The Senate is poised to launch an inquiry into options to help Qantas, with suggestions that the company’s chief executive, Alan Joyce, could be called to give evidence.

Labor, the Greens and independent senator Nick Xenophon have been in talks over the wording of a motion setting up a Senate committee inquiry.

Labor voted against the motion in the Senate on Wednesday but confirmed its support for an inquiry and proposed slightly narrower terms of reference, which should be considered by the Senate on Thursday. It is likely to pass.

The rural and regional affairs and transport references committee is expected to be tasked with considering what initiatives should be taken by the Abbott government “to ensure Qantas remains a strong national carrier supporting aviation jobs in Australia”.

In a challenge to the government’s stated intention to remove foreign ownership restrictions from the Qantas Sale Act, the proposed terms of reference say the options to be considered include a debt guarantee, an equity stake and “other forms of support consistent with wider policy settings”.

The proposal calls for an investigation into benefits provided by an Australian-owned Qantas; the level and forms of government support received by other international airlines operating to and from Australia; and ownership structures of other airlines.

The inquiry would also consider the potential impact on Australian jobs arising from the government’s plan to repeal part three of the Qantas sale act.

The terms of reference expected to be moved by Labor on Thursday are similar, but narrower than those included in a motion moved by the Greens and Xenophon on Wednesday. The new version does not explicitly ask for an investigation into the likely causes of the company’s financial decline and direct costs faced by Australian air carriers.

The Greens’ transport spokeswoman, Lee Rhiannon, said she was pleased the Greens had managed to secure Labor’s support for the inquiry.

“When the inquiry begins, the Greens will immediately move to have Qantas CEO Alan Joyce to be called to give evidence, and for Qantas’s books to be opened up to examination,” she said.

“Clearly there’s a problem with Qantas – we are on the verge of losing our national carrier and thousands of jobs going. A responsible government would be sitting down and looking at all the options.”

Xenophon, a harsh critic of Joyce’s performance, said it would be up to the committee to decide whether to call the chief executive to give evidence.

Labor’s transport spokesman, Anthony Albanese, said one of the options the inquiry should consider was “an equity injection which would of course produce a return to the government”.

“With regard to Mr Joyce I think that the Senate should feel free to ask him to attend,” he said.

The Coalition senator Ian Macdonald said the inquiry seemed to be “another waste of the very valuable time of the Senate and senators” because Labor and the Greens had already decided on the outcome.

Qantas last week announced plans to axe 5,000 full-time jobs and introduce wage freezes as part of a $2bn cost-cutting drive. The airline posted an underlying before-tax loss of $252m for the last six months of 2013.

The treasurer, Joe Hockey, said on Wednesday that anyone who cared about the future of Qantas would “be out there lobbying hard to get changes to the Qantas sale act” to ensure the airline was no longer put at a disadvantage to its competitors.

Cabinet decided on Monday not to provide Qantas with a debt guarantee but instead to pursue changes to the Qantas sale act, removing section 3, which includes a 49% cap on foreign ownership of the company and requires most of the operations, including maintenance, to be located in Australia.

But the bill faces defeat in the Senate, with Labor and the Greens both opposing it. The new Senate sits in July but is also unlikely to pass the legislation, with crossbench senators John Madigan and Xenophon and the Palmer United party signalling their opposition.

Unions met with Qantas management on Wednesday afternoon to discuss the company’s plan to impose wage freezes and cut jobs.

Labor, the Greens and independent senator Nick Xenophon have been in talks over the wording of a motion setting up a Senate committee inquiry. Labor voted against the motion in the Senate on Wednesday but confirmed its support for an inquiry and proposed slightly narrower terms of reference, which should be considered by the Senate on Thursday. It is likely to pass. The rural and regional affairs and transport references committee is expected to be tasked with considering what initiatives should be taken by the Abbott government “to ensure Qantas remains a strong national carrier supporting aviation jobs in Australia”. In a challenge to the government’s stated intention to remove foreign ownership restrictions from the Qantas Sale Act, the proposed terms of reference say the options to be considered include a debt guarantee, an equity stake and “other forms of support consistent with wider policy settings”. The proposal calls for an investigation into benefits provided by an Australian-owned Qantas; the level and forms of government support received by other international airlines operating to and from Australia; and ownership structures of other airlines. The inquiry would also consider the potential impact on Australian jobs arising from the government’s plan to repeal part three of the Qantas sale act. The terms of reference expected to be moved by Labor on Thursday are similar, but narrower than those included in a motion moved by the Greens and Xenophon on Wednesday. The new version does not explicitly ask for an investigation into the likely causes of the company’s financial decline and direct costs faced by Australian air carriers. webTitle: Lehman Brothers administrators left with £5bn surplus after creditors paid

fields.standfirst: PwC says UK arm of Lehman was not crippled by debts – but 'cash flow insolvent' because parent company collapsed
fields.body:
Banks, hedge funds and fund managers will recoup all the cash they were owed by the UK arm of Lehman Brothers when it collapsed five years ago, and the administrators said on Wednesday they expect to be left with a £5bn surplus.

These unsecured creditors will have received a total of £10bn by the time the final payment is made next month, leaving the administrators at PriceWaterhouseCoopers the task of settlements with claims from other parts of the Lehman estate.

Tony Lomas, the PwC partner leading the administration which began on September 15 2008, said it was "remarkable feat" that the unsecured creditors had been paid back in full. He said the administration of what is technically Lehman Brothers International (Europe) provided lessons for regulators in seeking solutions to tackling other banks which might be on the brink of collapse.

His view is that LBIE was not "balance sheet insolvent", that is crippled by debts or creditors, but "cash flow insolvent" because its parent company in the US had collapsed. The UK arm had $3bn (£1.8bn) of payments to make on the morning it collapsed but had no cash.

Regulators have been focusing on tackling the issue of balance sheet insolvency, he said, with bonds which can be called upon, or bailed in, during times of difficulty.

"LBIE offers an interesting example to regulators and central banks currently developing 'bail in' plans to address the 'too big to fail' problem. Whilst 'bail in' is intended to address pending balance sheet insolvency, PwC's experience dealing with LBIE clearly demonstrates the very sizeable potential need to support a firm's liquidity at the same time, where it has high volume, high value and complex trades pending at the point of its imminent failure," Lomas said.

There is another £5bn of surplus cash to be made available although legal battles could delay these payouts. PwC is on course to receive £1bn in fees from the administration which Lomas has previously warned could take at least another 10 years. More than 500 people are employed on the administration.

webTitle: Positive economic data upsets Hockey's doom and gloom budget narrative

fields.standfirst: From GDP growth to consumer spending to productivity, the economy is performing well above expectations
fields.body:
It’s nice to get some positive economic data, and the GDP figures showing 0.8% growth in the December 2013 quarter were well above expectations, so let’s have a look at the five things you need to know about today’s national accounts figures.

1. Not just real growth but nominal growth is up

Joe Hockey, as all treasurers must do when selling the budget, tried to put on a gloomy face regarding these figures, but there is no doubt they are good for his budget. As I wrote last month, the predictions outlined in December’s mid-year economic and fiscal outlook (Myefo), now look overly pessimistic.

The Myefo prediction for real GDP growth in 2013-14 was 2.5%. With growth in the first half of this financial year already at 1.4%, GDP would only need to average 0.5% growth in the next two quarters to meet that target. And given that in 10 of the past 11 quarters real GDP growth has been above 0.5% that’s a pretty good bet.

But even better for the Treasurer is the nominal GDP figure. This figure is more closely aligned with tax revenue – because taxes are paid in nominal dollars, not ones adjusted for inflation. In the Myefo, nominal GDP growth for 2014-15 was revised down from the 3.75% outlook contained in the pre-election statement put out by Treasury to a mere 3.5%.

Today’s figures show nominal GDP growing annually by 4.4% in trend terms and 4.8% seasonally adjusted. At the current rate, nominal GDP looks good to be at least one percentage point higher than predicted in the Myefo. That will lead to a much better tax revenue – especially when you consider private corporation profits rose 2.8% in the past 12 months – the best result since 2011.

2. The mining investment boom is over, but here come the exports.

In my last column I was pretty pessimistic about the end of the mining investment boom. Expected capital expenditure was well down, but as I also noted this also marked the start of the production/export phase of the boom. Today’s figures showed that quite clearly.

Net exports contributed 0.6 percentage points to growth over the past 12 months. In trend terms net exports have contributed a positive impact on GDP for the past seven quarters – the longest positive streak since before the mining boom began.

By contrast total private sector business investment detracted from GDP growth by -0.6 percentage points in the December quarter and by 0.3 percentage points over the past year.

We’re now beholden to mining exports for growth, not its investment.

3. Mining is still the king

But the change in the phases of the boom hasn’t changed mining still being the big driver of our economy.

Over the past 12 months mining contributed the most to GDP growth, closely followed by the financial and insurance services industry and the healthcare and social assistance industry.

The iron ore mining sector remains the biggest contributor in the industry to GDP growth, with the coal sector’s contribution declining over the past 18 months. The oil and gas extraction sector has for the past six months had a negative impact on GDP growth.

Overall the end of the investment mining-boom is reflected in the slight drop off in the contribution of the mining industry to GDP growth.

This slight decline is also reflected by, for the first times since the middle of 2012, the industry seeing the biggest annual growth of value added is not mining. Over 2013, gross value added in the agriculture and fisheries industry grew by 8.3%, relegating mining with 6.6% growth to second place.

Manufacturing recorded another 12-month period of decline, meaning the industry has not seen 12 months of growth since 2011.

4. Productivity continues to do well

Remember when the Fair Work Act was going to kill productivity due to excessive regulation and inflexibility? Yeah, relegate that prediction to the same bin as the wages boom.

The GDP figures showed annual productivity rose 1.7% in trend terms – reversing a mild decline over the past 12 months. But even better, looking over a longer term, which is much better at gauging the state of productivity as it can bounce up and down a fair bit, five yearly productivity growth is at its highest point since 2005.

If anyone wants to look for proof of the current IR system dragging down productivity, they’ll have to keep looking.

5. We’re starting to spend again

For the seventh quarter in a row the household savings ratio (measuring how much of net disposable income is being saved) declined in trend terms. The savings ratio in trend terms is now below 10% - the first time this has occurred since June 2010.

This is reflected by the annual growth of household consumption now at 2.5%, and the quarterly growth has increased for four consecutive quarters – the first time that has occurred since 2011.

Fortunately we have not gone silly such as we were in the early 2000s when our savings ration was actually negative – meaning we were effectively spending more than we earned – and when household consumption was growing by up to 6% annually.

But this increase does suggest some sort of improvement in consumer confidence. And we will need it, because while consumption by the national government contributed 0.1 percentage point to growth, an austere budget in May might see that reversed.

But these figures at least suggest Hockey will have more money to play with that he expected in December.

webTitle: Sunny weather drew record numbers to UK's outdoor tourist hotspots in 2013

fields.bodyText: Glorious weather last summer boosted visits to the UK's outdoor attractions in 2013, tourist chiefs said, while a series of blockbuster exhibitions swelled numbers at museums and galleries. Popular sights such as Kew gardens, London zoo and Stonehenge all enjoyed a leap in visitor numbers last year. Overall, Britain's main attractions welcomed 6% more people last year than in rainy 2012, with an 8% increase at outdoor destinations. The Royal Botanic Gardens in Kew, south-west London, had a 29% rise in visitor numbers, while at London zoo numbers rose 26.4% – thanks to the opening of the Tiger Territory exhibition – and Stonehenge was up 18.9%. The figures were published by the Association of Leading Visitor Attractions (Alva), whose members include the UK's most popular and important museums, galleries, palaces, castles, cathedrals, zoos, historic houses, heritage sites, gardens and leisure attractions. The 53 members manage nearly 2,000 tourist sites and have more than 100 million visitors a year – 25% of the annual UK total. Overall, London attractions enjoyed a 12% increase in 2013, with English attractions up 5% and Scottish attractions also up 5%. The British Museum in central London remained the UK's most popular visitor attraction for the seventh year running, with a 20% rise in visitor numbers, to 6.7 million, making it the museum's most successful year on record. It was helped by its sellout exhibition Life and Death in Pompeii and Herculaneum. Its new Vikings: Life and Legend exhibition opens on 6 March and is expected to be a big seller. In second place, up from third the previous year, was the National Gallery (6.03 million visitors), followed by the Natural History Museum with 5.35 million visitors. The Natural History Museum's director, Dr Michael Dixon, said: "Last year was another record-breaking one for the Natural History Museum. I believe this reflects the enduring appeal of museums, and our events and exhibitions showcasing our unparalleled collections and research. It also shows the continued success of the free admission policy and the public's real interest in science and environmental issues." Only 18 of the Alva venues experienced annual decreases in numbers of more than 10% last year. In 2012, by contrast, 33 locations had a double-digit decline from 2011. Other attractions with big increases last year included the Tower of London (up 18.4% to 2.89 million), the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich, south-east London (up 27% to 1.43 million) and Portsmouth Historic Dockyard, where the opening of the Mary Rose Museum resulted in a 55% rise in visitors to more than 674,000. Alva's director, Bernard Donoghue, said: "2014 is sure to be a momentous year, the 450th anniversary of the birth of Shakespeare. We are delighted that Shakespeare's Globe in London and the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford-upon-Avon, along with the South Bank Centre in London, are Alva's newest members. In 2013, the Shakespeare Birthplace Trust saw a 13% increase in visitor numbers, and they will build on this in 2014 by launching a brand new exhibition, Famous Beyond Words, later this month." He said further key anniversaries this year would generate huge interest : "The 100th anniversary of world war one will be commemorated with the re-opening of IWM London, part of Imperial War Museums, in July 2014 and The Great War in Portraits exhibition just opened at the National Portrait Gallery. The recently refurbished Tate Britain will no doubt see strong visitor numbers too." Tourism minister Helen Grant said: "It is fantastic news for the tourism sector that our top attractions received a boost in visitor numbers in 2013 and the government will continue to support the industry and promote Britain to the world as a great place to visit and do business with."
